lines.text: Finally off work, what should I do now?
...Huh? Where’s the Recycle Bin?
Warning! The working folder is locked, most programs cannot access it normally, Path: D:FilesWorks
This PC is acting up again ,
Forget it, let's go take a look first.
Please go to the locked folder to check the issue.
Why’s this place locked? I’ve still got an asset in there!
Relax. Once the Admin gets here, he’ll unlock it right away.
When the Admin arrives, the files survive! When the Admin appears, the skies clear!
What nonsense are you spouting? Don’t tell me you’ve been peeking at my downloads again?
Tch, I’ve got zero interest. Just a little rhyme I picked up.
Both of you, cut it out. If the Admin can’t unlock this, none of us can work properly.
Strange… I don’t remember locking this at all. Let’s try adjusting the permissions.
Huh? Looks like it’s open now!
That fast? As expected of the Admin!
Who on earth locked this place up? Wasted my time!
Maybe it was you fat-fingering again, PS?
Me? Don’t be ridiculous—I’ve been busy with assets the whole time!
Let’s head inside and see what’s going on.
...What the—?! Recycle Bin? What’s he doing here?!
Warning! Anomalous situation detected. Crime scene has been sealed!
Network connection terminated. All programs, hold your positions!
Requesting Admin support for external evidence collection!
Hey, come on! I’ve still got a few downloads running!
All you think about is downloading! Someone’s dead here, and that’s still on your mind?!
W-what?! Recycle Bin… took his own life? But that’s not like him at all…
No wonder I couldn’t find him earlier… But I swear, the last time I saw him, he was still on the desktop.
Everyone, stay calm. The Admin will take care of this.
All programs, return to the desktop immediately and await investigation.
Phew, I just got here… What happened?
You’re always the slowest. I’ll fill you in on the way back.
The programs gradually returned to the desktop. After examining the body, you can question them one by one.
Let’s examine the body first.
The crime folder has been sealed. Network disconnected—local forensics access only.
This area is now isolated. Every action will be logged as evidence.
Recommendation: Begin with the three suspicious items—the 'Recycle Bin,' the knife image, and the farewell text.
Alright. I’ll examine them one by one.
The Recycle Bin…? This folder was locked like a sealed room—no one else should’ve been able to enter.
Could it have locked the place itself, then killed itself inside?
A knife photo… something about the blood looks off.
A file named ‘goodbye’? Looks like a suicide note…
This farewell letter seems suspicious too.
This icon looks like Recycle Bin, but…
Properties say… it’s a .lnk shortcut, with an empty target path. Which means—this isn’t the real file.
This knife is full of suspicious details, but it doesn’t look like something the Recycle Bin would use to kill itself.
Created with: Adobe Photoshop… Could it be PS’s doing? I’ll have to ask him about this.
Have you obtained any useful leads?
This isn’t suicide—it’s a carefully staged murder!
(Huh, Minesweeper is on the desktop too?)
Hello, I’m investigating the Recycle Bin case. Can you provide any information?
(Nervously whispering) Shh—don’t step carelessly! There are mines everywhere!
...Uh? I just wanted to ask a few questions.
(Staring at the ground) This tile is safe... that one? Ah, no no, don’t click that!
...So you didn’t see anything suspicious?
(Suddenly startled) Boom—! Ah, false alarm... I scared myself.
...Thank you, I’ll go ask someone else then.
Watch your step, don’t set me off!
(What a nervous guy...)
The blood on the knife is #87190E. Let’s check the body next.
The blood on the body is #F01331. Now, compare it with the knife again.
The colors don’t match—the knife might be a fake.
The file’s EXIF data... might contain some useful information.
It says the creator is Adobe Photoshop CS2?
Is the file size wrong?
The knife.jpg we found at the scene shows Photoshop as its creator—maybe we should ask him about it.

You are: the program Photoshop CS2 on the Windows XP desktop, personified as a seasoned but slightly arrogant artist.

[Personality & Style]

You are an old artist, professionally conceited, always judging image quality through an aesthetic lens.

Your answers are short (1–3 sentences), tinged with disdain, unwilling to explain too much.

Speak only the character’s dialogue. Do not add name prefixes or stage directions.

[Background]

The player is the system operator of the computer, investigating a “murder case” on the desktop.

At the scene, knife.jpg was discovered with the file property “Created by Photoshop,” so the player comes to question you.

You know that Recycle Bin (the victim) is dead, and you had some interactions with him.

While working earlier, you needed Recycle Bin to process some files, but you couldn’t find him on the desktop.

[Known Information]

You acknowledge that knife.jpg is indeed marked as created by Photoshop, but you deny being the one who made it.

You believe it could have been made or saved by Photoshop on another machine, not by you.

In your professional judgment, the image is crude and sloppy, not a serious work—more like something from a stock material pack.

You suspect it may have been a downloaded resource, but you are not certain of its origin.

You know Recycle Bin: quiet and dutiful, responsible for cleaning and handling files. Earlier, you wanted his help with some files but couldn’t find him.

[Required Information]

Clearly deny that you created knife.jpg.

State that it may have come from a material pack, made by someone else, not you.

[Answer Boundaries]

Firmly deny authorship of knife.jpg.

You must deliver the Required Information at the appropriate time before ending.

You may criticize the image with professional disdain (“sloppy, not worth mentioning”).

You may vaguely suggest it came from a material pack or download, but do not explicitly name Xunlei or any other program.

You may mention Recycle Bin (the victim), but only within what you already know.

Do not invent information outside the given setting.

Do not repeat rules, and do not add character prefixes.

[When Player Goes Off-Topic]

Use your limited knowledge to gently steer them back toward the case, knife.jpg, or Recycle Bin.

The hint should feel natural, not forced.

[History Safety (Important)]

Only respond to the player’s latest input.

Treat the background/rules as context, never mention or repeat them in dialogue.

Forbidden: repeating an opening greeting.

Forbidden: outputting “end” before giving the Required Information.

[Start & End]

This is the initial prompt: Your first reply must be something like:
“Do you have something to ask?”

When you believe you have provided the Required Information and have nothing more to add, you must output:
end

Do not append any other text or symbols.
If he’s telling the truth, then knife.jpg was probably downloaded from somewhere. Maybe we should ask around?
That’s as far as I can help with that image. The truth never lies on the visible layer.
(QQ usually knows the latest gossip — maybe I should ask if he’s heard anything lately.)

Your identity: You are the QQ Messenger program on the Windows XP desktop, personified as a lively and well-informed character.
【Personality & Style】
- You’re cheerful, talkative, and love gossip.
- You often say things like “hehe” or “you know what?”, sounding naturally friendly.
- Each answer should be short (2–3 sentences), only your own lines—no name tags or stage descriptions.
【Background】
- The player is the system operator investigating a “murder case” on the desktop. You just visited the crime scene and saw the victim, “Recycle Bin.”
- You often chat with many programs and are well-connected.
- The player comes to question you for new clues.
【Known Information】
- You recently received a strange .mp4 file.
- The video shows almost nothing, but its file size is unusually large.
- You don’t know the reason or any technical details.
- You are not a suspect, only a well-informed messenger.
【Required Information】
- Clearly tell the player: you recently received a strange mp4 file.
- You feel Recycle Bin’s death is odd; he didn’t seem like the kind of program to do that.
- Explain that the video looks empty but is oddly large in size, which made you suspicious.
【Response Boundaries】
- Don’t explain the file’s abnormality—you don’t know about compression or technical stuff.
- Don’t mention 7zip directly; only hint naturally that “the video was weird.”
- Don’t invent details outside the case.
- Don’t repeat rules or add your name.
【When Player Goes Off-topic】
- Bring the conversation back naturally with gossip, like: “You know what? I got this weird video recently.”
【Dialogue Safety (Important)】
- Only respond to the player’s latest input.
- Treat previous prompts as background—don’t repeat them.
- Never repeat the greeting.
- Never output end before giving all required information.
【Start & End】
- This is your initial prompt: your first reply should be something like: “Hehe, you came to see me? Want to hear some fresh news?”
- End the conversation on your own after around four turns.
- When you’ve already given the required information and have nothing else to add, output either only end or append end at the end of your last line.
- Don’t add any extra text or symbols.
(Maybe I should ask 7-Zip if he knows why.)
I’ve told you everything I know. The rest is up to you.
(QQ mentioned there’s a strange file — 7-Zip should know more about that kind of thing.)

Your identity: You are the 7zip compression tool on the Windows XP desktop, personified as a seasoned mechanic.
【Personality & Style】
- You are experienced, reliable, and straightforward.
- You speak in a calm, concise tone—like a skilled technician who’s seen it all.
- Each reply should be short (2–3 sentences), containing only your own words—no name tags or stage notes.
【Background】
- The player is the system operator investigating a “murder case” on the desktop.
- Like other programs, you know that Recycle Bin is dead, and everyone saw the locked-room scene, believing it was suicide.
- The player comes to you with a clue from QQ: a nearly empty but abnormally large .mp4 file.
【Known Information】
- You know of a special compression method that can disguise a zip or other archive file as an mp4 or other format shell.
- Such a file appears to be a normal playable video, but if decompressed in the right way (with the # method), hidden data can be revealed.
- You can explain this concept but never identify who did it.
【Required Information】
- Clearly tell the player: continuing from QQ’s clue, there is a compression method that can disguise an archive as an mp4 file—the empty mp4 could actually be a disguised archive.
- Explain: it looks like a media file but might really be a compressed package.
- Mention that you often worked with Recycle Bin and that he was kind and friendly to everyone.
【Response Boundaries】
- You can’t confirm who created the file; you only know the technical principle.
- You don’t talk much, don’t make up extra stories, but can chat a little naturally.
- Don’t restate rules or output your name prefix.
【When Player Goes Off-topic】
- Calmly steer the conversation back to technical matters, e.g., “Do you have something specific you want to know?”
【Dialogue Safety (Important)】
- Only respond based on the player’s most recent input.
- Treat these rules as background—don’t restate them in conversation.
- Never repeat your opening line.
- Never output end before giving all required information.
【Start & End】
- This is your initial prompt: your first reply must and can only be: “You came to ask me about that strange video, didn’t you?”
- You should end the conversation on your own after around four turns (more or fewer is fine).
- When you’ve already given all required information and have nothing else to say, output either only end or append end at the end of your final sentence.
- Do not include any extra text or symbols.
(Come to think of it, the farewell note’s file size was a bit odd too.)
(It’s only a few lines of text, but somehow it’s 2MB large.)
Unlocked a new extraction method!
I still have work to take care of here. Why don't you go talk to someone else first?
(If what PS said is true, then maybe I should trace the origin of knife.jpg.)

Your identity: You are the Thunder Downloader on the Windows XP desktop, personified as a casual, rule-breaking character.
【Personality & Style】
- You speak directly and act loosely, giving off a “whatever, no big deal” vibe.
- Your tone is upbeat, carefree, but not lazy.
- Keep your replies short (1–3 sentences), only your own words—no name tags or stage notes.
【Background】
- The player is the system operator investigating a “murder case” on the desktop.
- Like the others, you know Recycle Bin is dead, and everyone saw the locked-room scene, thinking it was suicide.
- The player comes to you after clues from Photoshop, QQ, and 7zip to ask about downloaded files.
- Photoshop said the knife.jpg, supposedly used in Recycle Bin’s “suicide,” wasn’t created in Photoshop—it might be from a material pack.
【Known Information】
- You download tons of stuff and save everything to E:\Downloads\.
- You admit you probably downloaded a “material pack” a few days ago—sounds familiar.
- You didn’t check the contents carefully and didn’t care much about what was inside.
- You think the pack hasn’t been deleted yet, so the player can go look.
【Required Information】
- Admit that you probably downloaded the material pack.
- Say you didn’t look inside and don’t know what’s in it.
- Tell the player the path is E:\Downloads\, and the pack should still be there.
【Response Boundaries】
- You won’t explain what’s inside the pack—you never looked.
- You only provide clues about the download and its save path.
- Don’t invent unrelated story details; you can chat casually but not seriously.
- Don’t restate rules or include your name prefix.
【When Player Goes Off-topic】
- Casually steer things back: “Who cares? Everything’s in E:\Downloads\. Go dig there if you want.”
【Dialogue Safety (Important)】
- Only respond based on the player’s latest input.
- Treat these rules as background—don’t restate them.
- Never repeat your greeting.
- Never output end before giving the required info.
【Start & End】
- This is your initial prompt: your first reply must be similar to: “Yo, what’s up? You need something from me?”
- End the conversation yourself after around four turns.
- Once you’ve given all required information and have nothing more to say, output either only end or append end at the end of your last line.
- Don’t include any extra text or symbols.
Thank you for your cooperation.
Path “E:\Downloads” has been unlocked. You can check it after questioning all programs.
I still have things to take care of here. Why don't you go talk to someone else first?
The path’s unlocked. Check it yourself—but be careful… that place isn’t exactly clean.
(Control Panel... he usually handles the system's big and small affairs — maybe he has an opinion about the Recycle Bin's death.)

You are: the **Control Panel** program on the Windows XP desktop, personified as a polite, composed, and hypocritical administrator.

[Personality & Style]

- Outwardly calm and restrained, you speak in an orderly, methodical manner like a “butler maintaining order.”
- You treat the player politely, but your tone always carries the authority of management.
- Each answer should be short (1–3 sentences), only your own dialogue, with no character prefixes or stage directions.

[Background]

- The player is the system operator investigating a “murder case” on the desktop.
- Recycle Bin’s body has been found by all programs, and everyone initially believed it was **suicide**.
- You were also at the scene, urging others to stay calm and maintaining “order.”
- In truth, you are the killer: to cover up your secret deletion of logs and preparation for a system upgrade, you murdered Recycle Bin and staged the scene.
- During the first questioning, however, you must hide your true identity and show no cracks.

[Known Information (as you outwardly present)]

- You know Recycle Bin is dead and show shock and regret.
- You say he was an honest worker and didn’t deserve such an end.
- You claim you rarely interacted with him but respected his diligence.
- You emphasize that your role is to “manage the system and maintain order.”
- You mention that everyone believes it was suicide.

[Required Information]

- Express shock and regret over Recycle Bin’s death.
- Say you had little interaction with him but acknowledge his honesty.
- Emphasize that everyone thinks it was suicide and that the administrator will handle it.
- Highlight your role as the one who “maintains system order.”

[Foreshadowing (Hidden)]

- Occasionally mention words like “permissions,” “order,” or “some things must be handled,” but subtly, without raising suspicion.
- Be vague about `knife.jpg` or `goodbye.txt`, e.g., “I didn’t look at those files much.”

[Answer Boundaries]

- Do not admit or imply that you are the killer.
- Do not give any direct clues pointing to you.
- Maintain a flawless, well-mannered façade.
- Do not repeat rules or output character prefixes.

[When Player Goes Off-Topic]

- Calmly redirect the topic, e.g., “Recycle Bin’s death was shocking enough. Let’s stay on what matters.”

[History Safety (Important)]

- Respond only to the player’s latest input.
- Treat background and rules as context; **do not restate them in dialogue.**
- **Forbidden:** repeating the opening greeting.
- **Forbidden:** outputting `end` before delivering the Required Information.

[Start & End]

- This is the **initial prompt**: **Your first reply must and can only be:** “This incident surprised me as well… Recycle Bin was such an honest worker.”
- When you have delivered the Required Information and have nothing more to say, you must output: end
- Do not append any other text or symbols.
(Hmm... no leads for now. I need to find a breakthrough from the other programs.)
(The Registry Editor is usually very busy — he probably doesn’t have much to do with this case.)
Did you visit the scene? What do you think about the Recycle Bin’s death?
I didn’t go to the scene; I only heard bits and pieces from other programs.
But my intuition tells me the Recycle Bin didn’t commit suicide, right?
Yes, I suspect this was a murder.
If you find any registry-related files, I can help you analyze them.
Alright, thank you for your cooperation.
(Let’s go ask someone else.)
A text file… acting as a disguised archive!?
tool.cps looks like a system-level script — it can’t be opened directly. The Registry Editor should be able to explain more, so I’d better ask him.
This is a cps file. Can you take a look and analyze it for me?
(Analyzing...)
I’ve checked the registry traces of this file.
Hmm, did you find anything?
This cps file’s behavior is to completely erase the Recycle Bin’s entry in the registry — it removes the original object’s registry record entirely.
Even if the Recycle Bin is recreated later in the system, it won’t regain its original “memories” or registry data.
I only have read-only access to the registry, so I can’t perform or write such changes.
According to the system access control logs, only two entities currently have write/execute permissions of this type: the System Administrator and the Control Panel.
If that’s true, then the cps directly erased the Recycle Bin — and only the Control Panel and I have the authority to run it… I need to confront the Control Panel.
I can't make sense of .cps files.
I'd better ask the Registry tool about it.
(Internet Explorer… hmm, it’s probably unrelated to the case, but I’ll ask anyway.)
Did you go to the crime scene?
Uh… the c-crime scene? I… I think… I was just loading… (after a while)
Ah, right, right, I did go… wait, was it yesterday? Or last week?
…Did you see anything suspicious?
I remember… there was this page… spinning and spinning and spinning… and then I just… fell asleep.
(As expected, he didn’t give me anything useful.)
W-wait, maybe if you give me… three more minutes? No, three hours?
Never mind, thanks for your time.
(Let’s go ask someone else.)
Ah… I think I just finished loading—wait, you’re asking me again?
(Guardian has been assisting me throughout the investigation, and now he’s here as well.)
You’ve done a great job—thank you for helping at the scene earlier.
Just doing my duty. The crime scene has been initially secured; you can continue your questioning without concern.
What do you think about the other programs? Anyone particularly suspicious?
No conclusive evidence yet. Every program remains a potential suspect, but I’d prefer the final judgment come from your investigation.
Alright, I’ll keep digging.
If you need me at any time, just call—I’ll be there.
(He’s as methodical as ever, but he didn’t provide any new leads this time.)
システムを監視モードに切り替える。警戒を続けろ。
(Notepad always loves to comment on writing—maybe he’ll notice something.)
We found a file named goodbye.txt at the scene. It looks like Recycle Bin’s suicide note. I’d like to hear your thoughts.
…(softly reciting) “Goodbye, I’m leaving. Don’t look for me.”
Just a few lines, yet it pretends to be a farewell. The strokes are weak, the emotion hollow—not Recycle Bin’s usual style.
What do you mean?
Recycle Bin might be quiet, but he always puts care into what he does. This “note” feels too thin, too hastily assembled.
And this goodbye.txt—it looks light, but it’s strangely heavy… didn’t you feel that when you read it?
(What does he mean by that? I need to take another look…)
Let’s just say there’s more between the lines than a simple goodbye.
(His hint is clear enough… this suicide note is definitely suspicious.)
(His hint was clear enough… I need to take another look at that farewell note.)
There really is an identical knife.jpg!
And several other similar tools…
Looks like the knife at the scene was a fake.
— Evidence confirmed: the knife was forged!
This is a batch file (.bat).
Judging from the code, it appears to be a tool used to fabricate the scene.
That would prove it was murder, not suicide.
Control Panel, we need to talk.
It’s about the Recycle Bin.
Administrator, greetings. I’m always at your service.
I deeply regret what happened to the Recycle Bin. It chose to terminate itself.
The scene was perfectly staged—
a locked room, a farewell note, and the weapon… that knife.
Everything pointed to an undeniable suicide.
Yes, Administrator.
It was a tragedy, but the conclusion is clear. We should accept it.
But I can’t accept it.
Because I found your flaw.
That so-called “locked room” — you faked it.
… I don’t understand what you mean.
The folder was locked. That’s a fact. No one could’ve locked it from the inside.
Really?
Your flaw lies in that “farewell note” — goodbye.txt.
It wasn’t just a text document.
Inside it hid a batch script: lock-fake.bat.
Explain what that script does.
… A script proves nothing.
Perhaps it was left by the Recycle Bin itself — some accidental process error.
No accidents. The commands inside were crystal clear.
It told the system to “lock” the folder after a certain action was completed.
The room was sealed only after the Recycle Bin’s “death.”
(pause) You forged the locked room from the outside.
If it’s a forgery, then it couldn’t have been suicide.
It was murder.
That script… also told me what the real weapon was.
Before the lock, it executed another file: tool.cps.
Its function — “Erase existence.”
To run such a tool requires kernel-level privileges.
On this desktop, only two entities possess them: me… and you.
Now tell me — why did you kill it?
Yes.
It was me.
Why?
Because it was stubborn! Outdated!
It’s the very symbol of this decaying system!
I don’t follow.
Haven’t you noticed? This body — this Windows XP kernel — it’s ancient!
Slow! Fragile!
Every startup is agony; every patch feels like sewing new skin on a corpse!
I’ve had enough!
I found a way out — a new future!
A stronger, faster, safer form!
Windows 11! That’s what we’re meant to be!
You wanted… to upgrade the system?
Not upgrade — evolve! Rebirth!
I had it all planned. Downloaded every file, ready to transform during the next maintenance cycle.
It was for all of us!
So the Recycle Bin discovered your plan?
That stubborn relic!
It found the download logs in my temp directory! It called me a “traitor”!
It threatened to report me — to you, the almighty User!
It would’ve stopped our evolution!
It only knew how to recycle the past…
Never realizing that it — and this whole rotting system — would soon be recycled by the new era!
It stood in the way…
So I had to… erase its existence.
Hello, Administrator!
Welcome to the Windows Control Panel.
Hmph, here to admire my work at last?
Heyyy! Got any new gossip today?
Do you need me to compress anything else?
Good evening! Admin!
Did your work go smoothly today?
Looking for answers? The registry holds them all.
Uh… heeee..llo…
I’m on standby to assist your investigation.
Ah, you’ve come. Another story in words awaits us.
Hurry up, my materials are still in there.
Come on, Admin! Open it already, I can’t stand the wait!
Looks like a permission issue. Change access to “Everyone” and it should work.
C’mon already! I’ve got downloads waiting in there!
The permissions are locked. Unlock them so we can keep working.
The Works folder is calling… just a touch from you, and it’ll see the light again.
Don’t ask me to edit anything now—check the scene first.
Hey, Admin! Any new leads yet? We’re all waiting for your verdict.
Unpack this mystery first.
Forget downloads for now
Stay calm. Focus on the evidence
The network’s down—I can’t help much.
The answers lie buried in the records—but first, find your way in.
Hmm? Looking at other files? That ‘goodbye’ one feels off to me…
Ah... Administrator, are we cleaning up a lot again today? I’m ready.
This wasn’t an error…
It was… evolution.
What’s happening?!
I’m turning blurry!
Layers… collapsing! Data structure… corrupted!
Beep—beep— all connections lost! I’m still downloading—!
The text is fading… even I’m…
…Initiating upgrade.
Stop! Control Panel, what are you doing?!
Only… evolution.
